title: 105_s1185
content:
SECTION 1. PERIODIC PENSION BENEFITS STATEMENTS. Section 105(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require plans to provide participants with annual benefit statements, including total benefits accrued and nonforfeitable pension benefits. Section 105(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now requires plans to provide participants with annual benefit statements. For defined benefit plans, participants must receive a statement every 3 years showing benefit levels based on pay and service, including impacts of breaks in service or family leave. Multiemployer plans with more than one unaffiliated employer must provide statements upon request. Failure to disclose information may result in penalties under Section 502(c)(1)(A). Section 105(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now requires plans to provide participants with annual benefit statements. Amendments to the Act include penalties for failure to disclose information under Section 502(c)(1)(A) and conforming amendments to sections 101(a)(2) and 106(b). The effective date for these changes applies to plan years beginning after the issuance of regulations by the Secretary of Labor. The regulations require simplifying defined benefit plan calculations and ensuring statements are understandable by participants by December 31, 1998. SEC. 2. DISCLOSURE OF BENEFIT CALCULATIONS. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require administrators of employee pension benefit plans to provide participants or beneficiaries with information on benefit distribution calculations upon written request. This includes a worksheet explaining the calculation, related documents if available, and any other information prescribed by the Secretary. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require plan administrators to provide participants with distribution calculation information upon request, including a worksheet and any other details specified by the Secretary. Conforming amendments are made to sections 101(a)(2) and 106(b) of the Act. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. The Secretary has the discretion to impose penalties for failure to disclose information to participants and beneficiaries, with a maximum civil penalty of $100 per day per violation. Each violation per participant or beneficiary is considered a separate violation. Effective for violations after the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 4. The definition of a participant under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act is clarified to include individuals who were, are, or may become participants. SEC. 5. REVIEW OF DENIAL OF BENEFIT CLAIMS. The Model Alternative Dispute Resolution Procedure under Section 503 (29 U.S.C. 1133) allows plans to adopt a procedure for appeals of benefit claims denials. The Secretary will establish a procedure with neutral experts who may be called upon, and fees may be assessed to cover expert costs. The Secretary may reduce or waive fees for experts based on inability to pay. Notice must be given to individuals about the procedure for resolving benefits claim disputes. Effective date for amendments is after enactment of this Act.
